channel.title: Wash Post Health
channel.description: The Washington Post Health section provides coverage and analysis of health,healthcare,nutrition and fitness news,trends and policy. Post Health includes discussions and blogs about major health issues.

item.title: Compromise Rules Issued on Embryonic Stem Cells
item.description: The Obama administration issued guidelines yesterday limiting government-sponsored embryonic stem cell research to cells taken from excess fertility clinic embryos, a compromise based on its reading of public opinion about the cutting-edge science.
item.dc:creator: Ceci Connolly

item.title: Nanjemoy Health Services, a Nonprofit Clinic, Is a Safety Net in Charles County
item.description: One in a series on how the recession is touching lives.
item.dc:creator: Megan Greenwell

item.title: New High-Tech Legs Give New Mobility for Iraq Veteran at Walter Reed
item.description: He's Walter Reed's bionic man, a wounded warrior who walks on a pair of new battery-powered prosthetic legs outfitted with some of the most high-tech gizmos around.
item.dc:creator: Christian Davenport

item.title: Local, State Agencies Lack Resources to Ensure Food Safety
item.description: Local and state health officials trying to prevent food illness outbreaks are stymied by scarce resources, weak leadership from the federal government and bureaucratic barriers, according to a new study public health experts released yesterday.
item.dc:creator: Lyndsey Layton

item.title: Army officials say war concussions overdiagnosed
item.description: ATLANTA -- Mild brain injuries _ once considered an under-recognized problem in returning military troops _ are being overdiagnosed because the government is using soft criteria instead of hard medical evidence, an Army doctor and two other officials contend.
item.dc:creator: MIKE STOBBE

item.title: Epilepsy drug in pregnancy may lower child's IQ
item.description: ATLANTA -- Toddlers of moms who took the epilepsy drug valproate during pregnancy had lower IQs than the children of women who used other anti-seizure medicines, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: MIKE STOBBE

item.title: Going to the Mattress
item.description: The enemy is stealthy and bloodthirsty. It attacks innocent victims without warning, while they sleep.
item.dc:creator: Dana Milbank

item.title: Company says prostate cancer vaccine shows promise
item.description: -- An experimental treatment that takes an entirely new approach to fighting prostate cancer extended survival in a late-stage study, its maker announced Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: MARILYNN MARCHIONE

item.title: Testing tool to better detect preemie eye disease
item.description: WASHINGTON -- Dr. Thomas Lee painstakingly scrapes away spiderweb-like tentacles deep inside a premature baby's eye, scar tissue that is pulling apart the infant's retina.
item.dc:creator: LAURAN NEERGAARD

item.title: Addressing a child's health needs can become complex when the parents are no longer together.
item.description: Sean Smith knows his two children, ages 5 and 7, eat balanced meals. Still, he wanted to make sure they got all the right nutrients. So when the Rockville resident heard about special kids' vitamins, chewable like Gummi Bears, he wanted his children to take them.
item.dc:creator: Theola Labb√©-DeBose

item.title: Even a Dietitian Can Find It Hard to Craft a Diet That Covers All the Bases
item.description: My challenge: To meet all the daily nutrition standards in the federal government's guidelines without taking a multivitamin or other dietary supplement.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Huget

item.title: Some Gyms Open Their Doors to a Younger Set
item.description: Inside the Green Valley YMCA in Frederick County, the television-equipped treadmills were humming. A tall, lanky dude was running to the rhythm of CNN. An older couple sauntered on side-by-side machines, taking in a home garden show.
item.dc:creator: Jacqueline M. Duda

item.title: The Checkup
item.description: That Doughnut Ad In the new Dunkin' Donuts TV ad, three kids (and a dog) are in a darkened room, watching television. A "tractor beam" fixes on each child and suspends the kids in midair, drawing them toward the TV. Just in the nick of time, Dad appears in the doorway and announces he's got Dunkin'...
item.dc:creator: Adapted from voices.washpost.com/checkup

item.title: Losing Weight Is Easy. Losing Bad Habits Is Something Else.
item.description: This week we continue our series of tryout columns by four writers who would like to become Vicky Hallett's MisFits partner. The contenders remain anonymous -- but we'll identify the winner on May 5.
item.dc:creator: The Misfits

item.title: Study Questions Value of Private Cord-Blood Banks
item.description: Prospective parents face an array of medical decisions before their baby is born: Which pediatric practice to use? To circumcise, or not? What about prenatal testing to screen for possible genetic disorders?
item.dc:creator: Sandra G. Boodman

item.title: Kim Hart's The Download
item.description: Breaking into the health-care industry can be daunting. Doctors, hospitals, insurance companies and patients speak different languages and have vastly different needs.
item.dc:creator: Kim Hart

item.title: A Possible Step Toward Setting the Biological Clock
item.description: Scientists have produced strong new evidence challenging one of the most fundamental assumptions in biology: that female mammals, including women, are born with all the eggs they will ever have.
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: America's uninsured haven't shown collective power
item.description: WASHINGTON -- If the uninsured were a political lobbying group, they'd have more members than AARP. The National Mall couldn't hold them if they decided to march on Washington.
item.dc:creator: RICARDO ALONSO-ZALDIVAR

item.title: Area to Get More Than $73 Million in Child-Care Funds for Low-Income Families
item.description: Virginia, Maryland and the District will receive more than $73 million in federal stimulus funds to expand and improve child-care and immunization programs for low-income families, the Obama administration announced yesterday.
item.dc:creator: Chris L. Jenkins

item.title: 7th surgery shows face transplants gaining ground
item.description: -- Five years ago, it was the stuff of science fiction: Replace someone's face with one from a dead donor. But on Thursday, Boston doctors performed the world's seventh such transplant _ less than a week after one in France _ and plans are in the works for more.
item.dc:creator: MARILYNN MARCHIONE

item.title: Facing hard times, Shriners may close 6 hospitals
item.description: GREENVILLE, S.C. -- Shriners hospitals, which have provided free care since before the Great Depression, are considering closing a quarter of their facilities as donations stagnate, costs increase and the charity's endowment shrivels.
item.dc:creator: KATRINA A. GOGGINS

item.title: Obama Seeks to Create Seamless Transition of Electronic Medical Records Between DOD and VA
item.description: President Obama said yesterday that his administration will create an electronic record for veterans that will "contain their administrative and medical information from the day they first enlist to the day that they are laid to rest."
item.dc:creator: David Brown

item.title: Food Safety Efforts Have Stalled in Recent Years, CDC Says
item.description: Efforts to reduce the number of food-borne illnesses in the United States have stalled in the past three years, and some illnesses are on the upswing, giving new urgency to efforts to reform the nation's food safety system, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported yesterday.
item.dc:creator: Lyndsey Layton

item.title: Studies Find A Way Adult Bodies May Fight Obesity
item.description: Three new studies show that most adults have unexpectedly large and active deposits of a calorie-burning type of fat that biologists once thought disappeared after infancy.
item.dc:creator: David Brown

item.title: Battery-Powered Cigarettes Deliver a Low-Cost Nicotine Fix. Is That Good or Bad?
item.description: I had lunch, a cup of coffee and a smoke the other day at the offices of the American Legacy Foundation in downtown Washington. I puffed away for a good 15 minutes, savoring the irony.
item.dc:creator: Richard Leiby

item.title: D.C. Area Schools Need to Do More to Address Childhood Obesity, Report Says
item.description: Local schools need to do more to get students moving and track their weight data, according to a regional survey on childhood obesity released yesterday.
item.dc:creator: Annie Gowen

item.title: Studies of 'good' fat could help with weight loss
item.description: -- Fight fat with fat? The newest obesity theory suggests we may one day be able to do just that. Just like good and bad cholesterol, there apparently are good and bad types of body fat. Scientists until recently believed this good fat, which spurs the body to burn calories to generate body heat,...
item.dc:creator: LINDA A. JOHNSON

item.title: Awareness Campaign On HIV/AIDS Begins
item.description: The Obama administration began a five-year, $45 million media blitz yesterday to spark awareness about HIV infection and AIDS, saying that Americans have grown complacent about the deadly illness even though it represents "a serious threat to the health of our nation."
item.dc:creator: Darryl Fears

item.title: Lyme Disease Numbers Soar in Washington Region
item.description: The black-legged tick nymphs that have caused Lyme disease reports in the Washington region to soar will emerge with the spring flowers this month, and one thing is certain: They are hungry.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Halsey III

item.title: Some Women Choose Double Mastectomies to Guard Against Breast Cancer
item.description: Karen Aulner, 36, has never been given a diagnosis of cancer. She has, however, been watching her older sister fight the disease since 2000. So when Aulner tested positive in 2004 for a gene mutation that put her at high risk of breast cancer, she asked her doctor to remove both of her healthy br...
item.dc:creator: Rachel Saslow

item.title: Stimulus Plan Leaves Laid-Off Workers Awaiting a Health Insurance Bailout
item.description: Laid off last fall and left to find $1,400 a month for continued family health coverage, I felt as if I'd struck pay dirt when I learned in February that Congress had decided to spend billions helping millions of Americans like me retain our insurance. The promise of a 65 percent subsidy on the p...
item.dc:creator: Rick Schmitt

item.title: Amid Peanut and Pistachio Recalls, What Can Consumers Do to Ensure Food Safety?
item.description: Peanuts and pistachios have much in common. Neither is a true nut: the peanut is a legume, same as a bean or a pea, while the pistachio is a seed. Long dismissed as high-calorie snacks, both are enjoying newfound recognition as healthful foods, full of fiber, beneficial fats, vitamins and mineral...
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Huget

item.title: The MisFits Competition Is Trimmed to Four Candidates
item.description: To recap the action last week: You met our cast of contestants (punk rock aerobicizer, self-taught triathlete, muffin top, etc.) to replace Howard as my fellow MisFits columnist and voted online for your pick -- nearly 6,000 of you! We know the results were hardly fair: While one contestant asked...
item.dc:creator: Post

item.title: The MisFits: Marathoners Can Find a Way to Push Through the Wall
item.description: Starting this week, we are publishing columns by four writers who would like to become Vicky Hallett's MisFits partner. We'll identify the winner when he or she is chosen; the others will stay anonymous.
item.dc:creator: Post

item.title: Research Links Poor Children's Stress and Brain Impairment
item.description: Children raised in poverty suffer many ill effects: They often have health problems and tend to struggle in school, which can create a cycle of poverty across generations.
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: Demand for Nurses Lessens During Economic Downturn
item.description: For more than a decade as she raised two children, Sue Estes heard one story after another about how hospitals were desperately short of nurses.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Halsey III

item.title: China in bold move on volatile health care issue
item.description: BEIJING -- China announced Monday the outlines of a thorough reform of the health care system that pledges to provide improved services to all citizens by 2020, tackling a critical issue that has become a major source of public dissatisfaction.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER BODEEN

item.title: Cigarette Tax Boost Prods Some to Quit
item.description: For Tonette Lancaster, it just got to be too much one day -- the worry, the guilt and the money.
item.dc:creator: David Brown

item.title: WASA Director to Resign This Summer
item.description: D.C. Water and Sewer Authority General Manager Jerry N. Johnson will resign this summer after 12 years, a move that a District government leader who oversees the agency said was aimed at restoring public confidence over Johnson's mishandling of the fallout from the discovery of excessive lead in the...
item.dc:creator: David Nakamura and Carol D. Leonnig

item.title: FDA Hasn't Intensified Inspections At Peanut Facilities, Despite Illness
item.description: Despite four outbreaks of salmonella illness from peanut products in the past three years, the federal government has not changed the safety measures required of peanut companies or instructed its inspectors to test for the bacteria.
item.dc:creator: Lyndsey Layton

item.title: Montgomery Divided Over Proposal to Ban Bricks' Use in Sidewalks
item.description: To many urban dwellers and visitors, the brick sidewalks of downtown Bethesda, Capitol Hill and Annapolis are a charming, inviting part of the local landscape. But to others in high heels, behind strollers and especially in wheelchairs, the bricks can be a menace.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

item.title: Manufacturing Error Probably Tainted Pistachios, FDA Says
item.description: A basic error on the production lines of a California processing plant is thought to have contaminated its pistachios with salmonella, a top federal food safety official said yesterday.
item.dc:creator: Lyndsey Layton

item.title: Labor IG Audit Finds Many Failures in Worker-Safety Initiative
item.description: A special government program to improve worker safety in hazardous industries rarely fulfilled its promise, a Labor Department audit concluded yesterday, and over the past six years, dozens of deaths occurred at firms that should have been subjected to much tighter federal safety enforcement.
item.dc:creator: R. Jeffrey Smith

item.title: Procrastination: Avoidance and Arousal
item.description: Crammed full of boxes containing memorabilia that date back a decade and stacked high with yet-to-be read books and magazines, Tricia Sawyer's one-bedroom Arlington apartment reflects a problem that affects us all once in a while: procrastination. But for some people, like Sawyer, the tendency to...
item.dc:creator: Erica Davis Bak

item.title: Dr. Ian Smith Discusses The 4-Day Diet, 50 Million Pound Challenge and Tips for Losing Weight
item.description: Dr. Ian Smith, bestselling author of The 4 Day Diet, diet expert on VH1's Celebrity Fit Club and creator of The 50 Million Pound Challenge will take questions on losing weight.
item.dc:creator: Dr. Ian Smith

item.title: Help Choose a New MisFit
item.description: When Howard, my co-columnist, decided to leave fitness writing to be a foreign correspondent, he suggested we choose his replacement with a "Gong Show"-style contest. We've opted for more of an "American Idol" affair:
item.dc:creator: Vicky Hallett

item.title: Webcams Let Students Stay Connected to Their Classes Despite Serious Illnesses
item.description: Almost every day for the past six weeks, 7-year-old Becky Wilson has turned on her laptop, made sure the built-in webcam was working, and started a live video chat. Her bright blue eyes peer into the camera, and her face widens into a smile: Time for class!
item.dc:creator: Sindya N. Bhanoo

item.title: Medical Mysteries: Doctors Were Puzzled by Retiree's Rapid Decline
item.description: Weeks after his hip replacement surgery, Solomon Berkman started going downhill fast. The 70-year-old retired aerospace engineer, who had prided himself on his mental acuity, became vague and forgetful, unable to work the crossword puzzle that had been his daily routine. Usually gregarious, Berkm...
item.dc:creator: Sandra G. Boodman

item.title: Acai Has Become Popular, but Some Experts Question Claims About the Berries
item.description: How bad can the economy be if people are buying acai?
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Huget

item.title: The Checkup
item.dc:creator: Adapted from voices.washpost.com/checkup

item.title: Should Contender #10 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: FEMALE Age: 31 Height: 5-6 1/2 Weight: Really?!? Okay, 147 As a kid, I hated exercise. Or rather I hated the version of exercise espoused by a succession of "go run the mile!" P.E. teachers. But a series of events after college - some mental health concerns, a period of intense weight gain - caus...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #9 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: FEMALE Age: late 40s Height: 5-3 Weight: 125 There's something unjust about a muffin top above size 4 jeans. For years, I deluded myself that I was healthy because I was slender, didn't smoke or drink, and ate gobs of fruits and veggies. I occasionally jogged but wasn't committed to exercise. I t...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #8 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: MALE Age: 52 Height: 5-10 Weight: 155 I used to think I was tough. Not out-of-my-mind tough. Not Ben Cheever tough. Ben, son of the tormented writer John Cheever, is a self-brutalizing runner. He runs long and hard no matter how miserable the conditions. Of runners, he once wrote: "We're tough. W...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #7 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: FEMALE Age: 32 Height: 5-4 Weight: 170 Vote for me -- I can out-Danzig all the other columnists! For those who don't know, Danzig was the original frontman for the Misfits punk band. Like the singer, I am short, very vocal and sometimes clumsy. (Did you see him fall off the stage at the Ram's Hea...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #6 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: MALE Age: 38 Height: 6-1 Weight: 182 My pitch can be boiled down to a simple threat: Vote for me or something beautiful dies. And by "something beautiful," I mean me. And by me, I mean the new me. See, I recently won a six-month weight-loss contest, dropping the hero (sandwich) and getting with t...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #5 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: FEMALE Age: 33 Height: 5-7 Weight: 145 (but that's six weeks after giving birth!) In high school, I was mocked for my running form. Hunched over, face to the ground, I limped along, my right foot hitting my left ankle so that blood soaked my sock by run's end. My mother once asked me in the midd...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #4 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: MALE Age: 52 Height: 5-7 Weight: 162 What the next MisFits columnist needs most is a highly cultivated sense of self-loathing. I've had that since age 11 when a baseball teammate told me I looked like a pregnant bird running for a pop fly in left field. (Yeah, I dropped it.) Thereafter I began a ...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #3 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: MALE Age: 50 Height: 5-11 Weight: 195 MisFit? Please. The word was invented for me. Most of my weight is distributed awkwardly from the hips down (think of a large, fleshy Michelob bottle). I was the guy in your gym class who couldn't climb the rope. The guy in the back of your Pilates class who ...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #2 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: MALE Age: 56 Height: 6 feet Weight: 164 My father taught me to swim in the Atlantic Ocean, where every wave seemed six feet high. Lesson learned: Thanks for the help, Dad, but no thanks. I taught myself to ride a two-wheel bicycle. I made it to the end of the block feeling like I had wings. I hit...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Should Contender #1 be the Next Washington Post MisFit?
item.description: MALE Age: 32 Height: 5' 9" Weight: 174 Why do we say someone "lost" weight? From 1999-2002, I went from 265 pounds to 165, and it was a bit more complicated than misplacing my keys. It took a lot of hard work and trial-and-error. As we learned from "Rocky IV," people get the best fitness result...
item.dc:creator: washingtonpost.com

item.title: Part of Study Testing Experimental Treatments for Trauma Victims Is Shut Down
item.description: A key part of a controversial project that has been testing experimental treatments on trauma victims has been shut down after the researchers discovered that one new therapy offered no benefit and that patients receiving it appeared to die more quickly.
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: Debate Over Drugs For ADHD Reignites
item.description: New data from a large federal study have reignited a debate over the effectiveness of long-term drug treatment of children with hyperactivity or attention-deficit disorder, and have drawn accusations that some members of the research team have sought to play down evidence that medications do little...
item.dc:creator: Shankar Vedantam

item.title: D.C., Maryland, Virginia Hospitals Feeling Effects of Economic Downturn
item.description: It might have a reputation as a growth industry in good times and bad, but that does not mean the health-care sector is immune to the economic troubles affecting other parts of the business world.
item.dc:creator: Lori Aratani

item.title: A Vaccine Debate Once Focused on Sex Shifts as Boys Join the Target Market
item.description: When a vaccine designed to protect girls against a sexually transmitted virus arrived three years ago, the debate centered on one question: Would the shots make young girls more likely to have sex?
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: CDC Analysis Tracks Pet-Related Falls and Resulting Injuries
item.description: Federal government researchers yesterday filled in a blank spot on the map of life's hazards -- the part occupied by Spot, Fifi, the chew toy and the water bowl.
item.dc:creator: David Brown

item.title: House Calls Making a Comeback
item.description: W hen George Taler meets with a patient, he does all the usual things: He measures blood pressure, listens to the heart and lungs, takes a look in the mouth and ears, and updates the medical chart. But then he does something unusual: He checks out medicine containers in the bathroom, food in the...
item.dc:creator: Ranit Mishori

item.title: Prince George's County, Maryland, Has Second-Highest Rate of Sexually Transmitted Diseases, Official Says
item.description: Prince George's County continues to have the second-highest rate of sexually transmitted diseases in Maryland and the second-highest number of reported AIDS and HIV cases, according to the county's top health official. Prince George's trails only Baltimore in both categories.
item.dc:creator: Ovetta Wiggins

item.title: Agency Doubles Number With HIV and TB
item.description: The number of people worldwide infected with both HIV and tuberculosis is twice what experts had thought, although the incidence of TB worldwide is slowly falling.
item.dc:creator: David Brown

item.title: Va. Hospital Treats the Whole Person
item.description: At Fauquier Hospital in Warrenton, a patient doesn't have to worry about getting stuck with a chatty roommate: All 86 of the hospital's rooms are private. Restricted visiting hours are a thing of the past, too: Family and friends can drop by any time, day or middle of the night.
item.dc:creator: M.J. McAteer

item.title: The MisFits: Competitive Instinct and Team Spirit Can Get You a Long Way
item.description: In every race I run, I always manage to end up just behind my arch nemesis. It doesn't matter that I've never met this person before. Nor that this person knows absolutely nothing about our intense feud. Nor that it's a different person each time. All I know is I'm not letting Ms. Purple Shorts g...
item.dc:creator: Vicky Hallett

item.title: Libraries, Booksellers Face Anti-Lead Ban On Older Books for Kids
item.description: Rachel Merrill, mother of three, was holding innocuous-seeming contraband in her hand at an Arlington Goodwill store earlier this month: a 1971 edition of "Little House on the Prairie." This copy of the children's classic had just become illegal to resell because of concerns that some old books c...
item.dc:creator: Michael Birnbaum

item.title: Daily Red Meat Raises Chances Of Dying Early
item.description: Eating red meat increases the chances of dying prematurely, according to the first large study to examine whether regularly eating beef or pork increases mortality.
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: Blacks Suffer More Early Heart Failure
item.description: One in 100 black men and women develop heart failure before age 50, according to one of the first long-term studies to look at the life-threatening condition in younger adults.
item.dc:creator: Mike Stobbe

item.title: Probiotics: They Sound Good, but How Friendly Are They?
item.description: What exactly is going on in those Activia ads, anyway?
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Huget

item.title: FDA Must Reconsider Its Plan B Age Limit, Judge Rules
item.description: A federal judge ordered the Food and Drug Administration yesterday to reconsider its 2006 decision to deny girls younger than 18 access to the morning-after pill Plan B without a prescription.
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: British Reality TV Star Jade Goody Dies of Cancer
item.description: LONDON, March 22 -- Jade Goody, the 27-year-old reality TV star whose battle with cervical cancer was chronicled by media cameras, which followed her even as she picked out her grave, died early Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Sullivan

item.title: The Checkup
item.description: Diets That Work Even time-tested, popular and well-respected regimens such as Weight Watchers quickly brought out the worst in me. It's taken me years to understand that my body does best, nutrition-wise and weight-wise, when I manage to get busy with other concerns and not allow myself to obsess...
item.dc:creator: Adapted from voices.washpost.com/checkup

item.title: Searching for a Cure-All at HGS
item.description: Rockville-based Human Genome Sciences is still reeling from Wall Street's unexpected drubbing earlier this month in reaction to the biotech company's long-awaited study of a hepatitis C drug it is developing for a mass market.
item.dc:creator: V. Dion Haynes

item.title: Nestl√©'s Inspectors Saw Rat Droppings, Rejected Peanuts
item.description: Nestl√© USA, considering whether to buy ingredients from Peanut Corporation of America, twice sent its own inspectors to check out the company. Both times, they rejected the company after finding sanitary problems at its facilities in Georgia and Texas, noting rat droppings, live beetles, dead...
item.dc:creator: Lyndsey Layton

item.title: Fairfax School Board Votes Against Time Change
item.description: The Fairfax County School Board late last night killed a plan to rearrange bus routes and school start times to give high school students an extra hour of sleep.
item.dc:creator: Michael Alison Chandler

item.title: Richardson Died From Clot That Compressed Brain
item.description: Natasha Richardson, the British actress who fell during a ski lesson on Monday and later in the day lapsed into a coma, died of a large blood clot compressing her brain, New York City's medical examiner said yesterday.
item.dc:creator: David Brown

item.title: Obama Drops Plan to Bill Veterans' Private Insurers
item.description: President Obama yesterday abandoned a proposal to bill veterans' private insurance companies for the treatment at VA hospitals of combat-related injuries amid an outcry over the measure from veterans' service organizations and members of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Philip Rucker

item.title: Teenage Birthrate Increases For Second Consecutive Year
item.description: The rate at which teenage girls in the United States are having babies has risen for a second year in a row, government statistics show, putting one of the nation's most successful social and public health campaigns in jeopardy.
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein and Donna St. George

item.title: Prostate Cancer Screening May Not Significantly Reduce Deaths, Two Studies Find
item.description: Men are being urged to carefully consider risks before undergoing prostate cancer screening in the wake of two large, long-awaited studies that did not produce convincing evidence that routine testing significantly reduces the chance of dying from the disease.
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: A Silenced Drug Study Creates An Uproar
item.description: The study would come to be called "cursed," but it started out just as Study 15.
item.dc:creator: Shankar Vedantam

item.title: In AIDS Crisis, Serious Times Call for Serious Measures
item.description: In response to a report released Monday on the HIV/AIDS crisis in the District, city officials say they plan to develop a new and improved public awareness campaign. Such efforts will no doubt take time and involve focus groups and require lots of data and even more money.
item.dc:creator: Courtland Milloy

item.title: Experts Advise Moderation When Returning to Exercise After an Illness
item.description: Man, did I feel lousy. Coming down the stairs one frigid Monday morning recently, I was an unsteady, two-ton monster with a spike hammered into my skull. Gait, heavy. Head, foggy. I stood at the dining room window looking out at the yard. A light snow floated before my eyes, but its loveliness wa...
item.dc:creator: Steven E. Levingston

item.title: Even 'Snake Oil' Can Help Patients Heal
item.description: Our conference was being held over lunch, but Pat, a middle-aged health-care consultant, did not touch a bite of her food. When I asked if something was wrong, she revealed her lifelong battle with Crohn's disease, an inflammation of the bowels that causes diarrhea and abdominal pain.
item.dc:creator: Manoj Jain

item.title: Scientists Speak Out Against Federal Funds for Research on Alternative Medicine
item.description: The impending national discussion about broadening access to health care, improving medical practice and saving money is giving a group of scientists an opening to make a once-unthinkable proposal: Shut down the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine at the National Institutes of...
item.dc:creator: David Brown

item.title: D.C. Officials Pledge Increased HIV/AIDS Testing
item.description: A report showing that 3 percent of D.C. residents are infected with HIV or AIDS is probably an undercount, and the prevalence of the disease is probably worse than is known, according to Shannon L. Hader, director of the city's HIV/AIDS Administration.
item.dc:creator: Darryl Fears and Jose Antonio Vargas

item.title: Comparison Shopping for Medicine
item.description: What's best for insomnia -- Lunesta, at about $6 a pill, or Zolpidem, at $2?
item.dc:creator: Ceci Connolly

item.title: The Checkup: Health in the News and in Your Life
item.dc:creator: Adapted from voices.washpost.com/ckeckup

item.title: Two Books Suggest Weight Loss Requires Taking a New Approach to Food
item.description: A recent study showed that people wishing to lose weight could do so more or less equally well by following any of four diets featuring different ratios of fat, protein and carbohydrates (mimicking several popular diet regimens), so long as they consumed sufficiently few calories.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Huget

item.title: Millions Embrace Acupuncture, Despite Thin Evidence
item.description: Kaiya Larson pressed a small, thin needle against the patient's skin.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Edwards

item.title: Don Imus Says He Has Prostate Cancer
item.description: Don Imus, the sometimes caustic and always controversial radio host, announced on the air this morning that he has Stage 2 prostate cancer.
item.dc:creator: Howard Kurtz

item.title: THE MISFITS
item.description: No MisFits column this week. Howard has left to become The Post's man in Jerusalem, and Vicky is on her honeymoon. She will be back next Tuesday, writing about the importance of competition in getting exercise.
item.dc:creator: The Misfits

item.title: At Least 3 Percent of D.C. Residents Have HIV or AIDS, City Study Finds; Rate Up 22% From 2006
item.description: At least 3 percent of District residents have HIV or AIDS, a total that far surpasses the 1 percent threshold that constitutes a "generalized and severe" epidemic, according to a report scheduled to be released by health officials tomorrow.
item.dc:creator: Jose Antonio Vargas and Darryl Fears
